awd_titl_txt: Literature Analysis and Synthesis of Women of Color in Technology and Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will review and synthesize existing literature on factors that impact the interest, participation, retention and success of women of color in computing and technology fields.  This type of project informs areas for future research and helps to identify promising practices that others can implement.  The project will result in a report to help inform those who are practitioners in STEM education, STEM employers, and STEM policy makers.   

This project is a mixed-methods meta-synthesis that will analyze and integrate the findings from empirical research on the factors that affect the retention of women of color in technology and computing higher education and careers. Focusing on literature produced since 2000, this synthesis will address the main research question: According to the existing empirical literature, what factors affect the experiences, participation, and advancement of women of color in technology and computing from the stages of early college education through their careers?  The goals of the project are to: (1) build new knowledge and understanding of the factors affecting the retention of women of color in technology and computing; (2) identify gaps in research; (3) inform leaders in the field about promising policies and practices that retain women of color in technology and computing; and (4) make methodological contributions through the testing and refinement of meta-synthesis tools and processes.  This project is supported by the Education and Human Resources Core Research Program, which funds fundamental research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Literature Analysis and Synthesis of Women of Color in Technology and Computing (LASOW; HRD-1760845) was a three-year meta-synthesis project led by Maria Ong, Ph.D., and Nuria Jaumot-Pascual, Ph.D. (TERC), with the objective of advancing the understanding of lived intersectionalities of women of color in computing higher education and careers. This qualitative meta-synthesis examined research published in a 20-year time frame (1999-2019) on the experiences of African American and Black, Asian and Asian American, Latinx and Hispanic, Native and Indigenous, and mixed race/ethnicity women across three different career levels: undergraduates, graduates, and professionals. The project's main research question was: What factors affect the experiences, participation, and advancement of women of color in computing from the stages of early college education through their careers? 

The LASOW team systematically searched, selected, and reviewed thousands of pieces of literature, then sifted through them to identify 45 pieces that reported on empirical research on women of color in computing disciplines. The team then analyzed the pieces using methods of thematic analysis. The intellectual merit of the project stems from the contribution to the existing knowledge base through identification of barriers and supports that influence the persistence of women of color in computing higher education and careers. Some of these factors are described below.  

Barriers for Women of Color in Computing Higher Education: 

  • Several studies described computing departments as environments that had a culture of hostility and exclusion against women of color at both the undergraduate and graduate levels.  
  • Majority male professors and peers were main contributors to this hostile culture through reinforcing negative stereotypes about groups to which women of color belonged and committing acts of racial and gender discrimination and harassment against them.  

Barriers for Women of Color in Computing Careers: 

  • Multiple studies reported on women of color computing professionals experiencing hyper-masculine, "bro" cultures within the workplace. Women often felt isolation and exclusion and were also victims of sexism and sexual harassment.
  • Women of color in computing reported impostor syndrome and having to modify their behaviors (such as how they spoke or dressed) to blend into the workplace and avoid instances of racialized and/or gendered discrimination.   

Supports for Women of Color in Computing Higher Education: 

  • Numerous studies found that student STEM organizations, like Latinas in Computing, served as counterspaces for women of color. These groups provided social support and resources, such as access to mentors.  
  • A common factor of persistence was women of color wanting to serve as mentors and role models in computing for future generations of students of color, particularly girls of color.
  • Historically Black colleges and universities created unique cultures of support for both undergraduate and graduate women who pursued computing.

Supports for Women of Color in Computing Careers: 

  • Several studies revealed giving back as a motivator for women of color to persist in the workplace. They especially wanted to serve as mentors and leaders and to share their experiences with other girls and women of color.  
  • Women of color in the workplace relied on their own agency to persist in their careers, such as integrating their creativity and problem-solving skills into their work and seeking counterspaces outside of the workplace.  
  • Having access to mentors at the career-level provided women of color with support to help them navigate the workplace and gain insights to advance in their careers.  

Additionally, LASOW created a future research agenda by identifying research gaps that need to be filled. Also, the methods that were developed and refined in LASOW have been leveraged in an NSF BCSER grant, Institute for Meta-Synthesis (HRD-2024967; PIs Ong and Jaumot-Pascual) to teach meta-synthesis methods to more than 2,000 research professionals, STEM faculty, and graduate students.

The broader impacts of LASOW stem from the actionable recommendations to departments, institutions, workplaces, STEM education researchers, and policymakers (e.g., Jaumot-Pascual et al., 2021). Communicated through academic and community-based conferences and publications, these recommendations can contribute to the transformation of how higher education supports positive outcomes for women of color in computing, and how corporations and other institutions can engage, retain, and advance them in the workforce. In total, the LASOW team wrote four synthesis manuscripts describing their methodology and findings about women of color in computing higher education and professions, and team members continue to publish project findings. The team also presented at numerous conferences and workshops, including the 2021 RESPECT conference, The Boston Club, Boston University, AERA, and the National Academies. Additionally, findings emerging from LASOW will be published in the National Academies report in Fall 2021. 

Publication:

Jaumot-Pascual, N., Silva, C. B., Martinez-Gudapakkam, A., & Ong, M. (2021). Women of Color in Computing Graduate Education: Structural Supports and Navigation Strategies for a Hostile Culture. In Proceedings of 2021 Research on Equity and Sustained Participation in Engineering, Computing, and Technology (RESPECT) Conference, pp. 1-9. https://www.terc.edu/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/WOCinCSGraduateEd_RESPECT_NOTBlinded_FINAL.pdf
